content.question:
Let random variable <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the the number of visitors to a certain museum during a given day. The following table shows the probability distribution of the random variable.

Which of the following claims about the distribution of random variable <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is best supported by the histogram?

choices.label: The most likely number of visitors to the museum on a given day is between 450 and 500.
The mean number of visitors to the museum is much less than the median number of visitors.
The mean number of visitors to the museum is much greater than the median number of visitors.
On a given day, the number of visitors from 100 through 500 will occur with equal probabilities.
On a given day, it is equally likely for the museum to have less than 300 visitors as it is to have more than 300 visitors.

content.answer: On a given day, it is equally likely for the museum to have less than 300 visitors as it is to have more than 300 visitors.

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

topic.text: 4.7: Introduction to Random Variables and Probability Distributions

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
